section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need five Connecting Cubes and one 5-frame for each child. You may use 5-frames from earlier in the year, or mark out new ones using evenly-sized squares in a row on a piece of paper.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Mole Catches the Sky, we counted Mole’s animal friends.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Review the use of 5-frames to subitize and track an amount up to five. Demonstrate counting two, three, and four, counting up or down in the 5-frame.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will use your 5-frames to keep track of animal friends who are going to a party at Mole’s house. Let’s see how many friends she can fit in her home!
The party starts with Mole at home with Bird and Frog. Mole’s home can fit five friends in all. How many more friends can join them?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the 5-Frame Have children count three Connecting Cubes and place them on the 5-frame. Guide them to use the empty boxes to determine how many more friends can join. Encourage them to give their answers without counting one at a time.
Repeat Continue the activity by adding and removing friends. For example: Frog leaves, and Rabbit and Squirrel come over. How many friends are at Mole’s party? How many more can join?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How do you know how many friends there were in all? How did the numbers change during the activity? How does the 5-frame help you count?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Below each square in the 5-frame, label the boxes with the numerals 1 through 5. Use these labels for the beginning of the activity, then hide or cover them so children can practice without them.

Provide children with 10-frames and tell the story about a group of 10 friends instead. Then have students represent the number of friends on the 10-frame with connecting cubes. Challenge them to say how many more cubes they need to make 10 friends in all.

For children who need more language support, frequently practice counting aloud with the class. Children may first memorize the number sequence 1 to 5, and then connect the words to their meaning. Use the number words frequently during class time for increased practice.

Placing small objects onto the 5-frame requires dexterity. Frames can be enlarged for children who may have less precise fine motor skills. A fun modification for the game to support all learners with fine motor skills is to use tongs or tweezers to pick up objects and place them on the frame.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need five Two-Color Counters for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Mole Catches the Sky, we talked about how the friends showed that they cared by sharing in the work of giving Mole the sky.

In this activity, you will use Two-Color Counters as treats you are sharing with a partner. You will put some “treats” on the table for your partner, and your partner will say how many you shared without counting. Then, you will both count to check the answer.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Pair children and assign them to be Partner A or Partner B. Say, Partner A, put out some treats! You can put out any number you want. Guide Partner As to place however many counters they want on the table to share with their partners. Partner B, how many treats did Partner A share? Guide Partner Bs to say how many counters are on the table. Encourage them to subitize—say the number without counting.
Extend Have partners check Partner B by counting the number of Two-Color Counters Partner A shared. Encourage them to flip the counters over as they count to keep track of the number.
Repeat Continue the activity for several rounds, swapping which partner places counters first.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How could you tell how many treats your partner shared with you? How did you work together to check your answer? How did it feel to share with someone?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Have children start with three Two-Color Counters. Model sharing counters with a child as your partner, demonstrating choosing a random number of counters, subitizing, and then working together to count to check the answer.
Challenge partners to share one more or less counter than their partner did. For example: Partner B, how many counters did Partner A share? Can you share one less counter than four?

Review key vocabulary, such as treats, how many, share, and numbers 1–5. Point to the Two-Color Counters you would like each child to subitize while asking how many, and have children use their fingers or point to a numeral card to show the amount.
Children who may need extra support can sit near or be paired with a teacher to help them focus.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need five Connecting Cubes for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Mole Catches the Sky, we talked about how many animal friends were working together and how each helped Mole.

In this activity, we will use Connecting Cubes to represent Mole and four of her friends. You will move each friend into Mole’s home and, without counting, tell how many friends are in the home and how many are outside.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Give each child five Connecting Cubes. Say, Let’s have Mole go into her home first. Guide children to move one Connecting Cube forward to represent Mole going into her home. Ask, How many friends are in Mole’s home? How many are outside? Guide children to answer without counting the cubes.
Extend Encourage children to count the cubes once they have answered to check their subitizing. Make sure children count in sequential order.
Repeat Have children move other friends into Mole’s home one by one, each time asking children to subitize how many are inside the home and how many are outside.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How were you able to tell how many friends were inside and outside without counting them one by one? Earlier in the week, we used a 5-frame to help us work with numbers. Is it harder to tell how many cubes there are without using a 5-frame?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start with only three friends in all, and add more cubes as children are ready. Help children arrange the Connecting Cubes in an array that more easily shows how many there are, such as straight lines of two rather than a scattered grouping.
Increase the number of Connecting Cubes to 10. Challenge children to create their own groupings, and tell how many are in each group without counting.

Review numbers 1–5. Use Number Cards if necessary, and have children point to the Number Card that represents the amount in each group. When asking children to subitize a group, point to it and circle your finger around the cubes you would like the child to subitize.

Have children sit separately, facing away from each other. Go to each child individually to ask how many Connecting Cubes are in each group. Children may focus better when they have space to work alone and your full attention when answering questions.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need various manipulatives in groups of five because each child will use a different group of five manipulatives. One child will have five Connecting Cubes, one child will have five red Pattern Blocks, etc.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read We Have Soup, we talked about how working together makes everything better. We also talked about how many vegetables would go into a real soup.
In this activity, we will make our own soup using objects to represent vegetables. I will ask each of you for a certain number of your vegetable, and you will bring me that amount.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Choose a manipulative for each child, and give each child a set of five (five yellow Pattern Blocks, five Two-Color Counters, etc.). Ask, How many vegetables do you have? Encourage children to answer without counting.

Make Soup Ask a child to give you a certain number of vegetables: Please add three of your vegetables to the soup. Guide the child to move three manipulatives into the center of the table. Ask, How many vegetables do you have left? Can you tell me without counting?
Repeat Ask other children to add vegetables to the soup until all children have had a turn. Request different numbers of vegetables from each child, and always ask, How many do you have left?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Soup is warm because we heat it on a stove. Heat is a type of energy. We get heat from sources like fire and electricity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start with three manipulatives for each child. Model adding vegetables into the soup and organizing your leftover manipulatives into a line that makes them easier to subitize.
Challenge children to tell you how many vegetables are in the soup each time more are added. As the numbers grow too high to subitize, encourage children to count each vegetable aloud.
Review key vocabulary, such as soup and vegetables. Have children point to the Number Card that represents how many vegetables they have left over.
Designate an area across the room as the soup pot, or bring in a bowl or pot and set it on a nearby table. Have children stand up and bring their vegetables to the soup when asked.
